data.name: sortOf function
data.description:
The usual "sort" function sorts arrays in a descending or ascending order. But then there is a "sortOf" function, which is a sort of "sort" function with a twist - it can sort arrays in an arbitrary order. Given two sortable arrays with matching lengths, it sorts the first array in the same order as that of the second array, whatever it may be. For example, the "sortOf" of [10, 20, 30] with [4,6,2] as a reference array will produce [20, 30, 10]. 

In this exercise, create an Array method "sortOf" that takes a single argument - a reference array of the same length, and returns a new array with the old elements arranged in the order of the reference array.

Examples: 

[1.0, 2.5, 4.0, 0.0].sortOf([-2, 100, 2.0e10, 100.00001]) = [0.0, 1.0, 4.0, 2.5]

['ABC','DEF','GHI','JKL','MNO','PQRS','TUV','WXYZ'].sortOf([7,6,2,3,4,8,9,5]) = ["PQRS", "MNO", "ABC", "DEF", "GHI", "TUV", "WXYZ", "JKL"]
